summary: This document is a series of forwarded emails from whistleblower Chris Dilorio to SDNY judges, appealing a preliminary denial of his 2015 whistleblower award claim. It alleges massive, ongoing securities fraud involving illegal naked short selling and money laundering through OTC markets, facilitated by SEC corruption and involving entities like Knight Capital/KCG/Virtu Financial (NITE), Citadel Securities (CDEL), and individuals including Michael Milken, Leon Black, and Jeffrey Epstein. It connects these activities to a broader network of financial figures and institutions.

persons.name: Chris Dilorio
persons.context: Author of the emails, alleging massive securities fraud, SEC corruption, and obstruction related to illegal naked short selling and money laundering through OTC markets.

persons.name: Michael Milken
persons.context: Referred to as the central figure whose 'flunkies' are involved in bailing out criminal entities and operating money laundering shells. Alleged to own the SEC via the Milken Institute.

persons.name: Leon Black
persons.context: Described as a 'Milken flunkie' connected to Jeffrey Epstein (ESSW).

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Mentioned in connection with Leon Black (ESSW).

persons.name: Ken Griffin
persons.context: CEO of Citadel (CDEL). Accused of knowingly lying to Congress about the SEC eliminating illegal naked shorting and of structuring his business to hide fraud.

persons.name: Doug Cifu
persons.context: CEO of Virtu Financial (VIRT/NITE). Accused of accounting fraud, misleading investors, and threatening analysts. Admits retail/OTC trading drives revenue.

persons.name: Rich Handler
persons.context: CEO of Jefferies (JEF). Alleged to have a corrupt relationship with the SEC/SDNY, benefiting from the bailout and merger of the 'criminal entity' Knight/KCG.

persons.name: Melissa Hodgman
persons.context: SEC official (referred to as Hodgman/Strzok). Criticized for a pathetic response to OTC market fraud, suspending only 15 dark shells.

persons.name: Peter Strzok
persons.context: Mentioned in conjunction with Melissa Hodgman (Hodgman/Strzok) regarding the SEC's response.

persons.name: Jane Norberg
persons.role: SEC Office of the Whistleblower Chief
persons.context: SEC OWB Chief. Accused of creating extraordinary reasons to deny the author's whistleblower award and failing to produce the full record.

persons.name: Jay Clayton
persons.context: Former SEC Chairman. Accused of not recusing himself from the VIRT/KCG merger approval despite conflicts from his time at Sullivan & Cromwell, and of protecting fraud.

persons.name: Michael Piwowar
persons.context: Former SEC Commissioner and Milken Institute Executive Director. Called as an 'expert witness' by the Senate and argued for payment for order flow.

persons.name: Hester Peirce
persons.context: SEC Commissioner, associated with the Mercatus Center and Kochs.

persons.name: Steve Cohen
persons.context: Described as a 'flunkie scumbag' who got his start in criminal bucket shops controlled by Milken.

persons.name: Felix Sater
persons.context: Described as a 'flunkie scumbag' who got his start in criminal bucket shops controlled by Milken.

persons.name: Bill Ackman
persons.context: Described as a 'flunkie scumbag' who got his start in criminal bucket shops controlled by Milken.

persons.name: Carl Icahn
persons.context: Described as a 'flunkie scumbag' who got his start in criminal bucket shops controlled by Milken.

persons.name: Dan Kamensky
persons.context: Subject of an SEC/SDNY complaint. The author claims his information led to Kamensky's plea deal but the SEC obstructed investigation to protect Handler/Jefferies.

persons.name: Alexander Blostein
persons.context: Goldman Sachs analyst covering NITE/VIRT. Accused of knowing OTC volumes drive revenue but omitting this from his models.

persons.name: Richard Repetto
persons.context: Sell-side analyst (perma pumper) covering NITE/VIRT. Implied to have a questionable relationship with the company.

persons.name: Glenn Hutchins
persons.context: Former Blackstone, co-founded Silver Lake, bought SunGard. Formed North Island with former NASDAQ CEO Greifeld, a top shareholder in NITE/VIRT. Implicated in money laundering.

persons.name: Robert Greifeld
persons.context: Former NASDAQ CEO. Partnered with Glenn Hutchins in North Island, a top NITE/VIRT shareholder. Former CEO of SunGard, involved in transactions with NASDAQ and Russian ruble conversion.

persons.name: Adena Friedman
persons.context: NASDAQ CEO who signed off on NASDAQ's acquisition of the BRUT ECN from SunGard.

persons.name: Jared Fishman
persons.context: Sullivan & Cromwell colleague of Jay Clayton. Accused of playing a key role in keeping NITE/VIRT running and involved in the CardWorks/ALLY fraud.

persons.name: Sean Galvin
persons.context: Third NITE/VIRT CFO in just over a year, accused of keeping the fraud up and running.

persons.name: Joshie Sason
persons.context: Bag man involved with Hanover/Magna and money laundering shells like CGFIA, IMDS. Subject of an SEC complaint which the author claims is based on his information.

persons.name: Justin Keener
persons.context: Bag man involved with JMJ and money laundering shells like Blink Charging. Barred by FINRA as a 'Bad Actor.'

persons.name: Paul Berger
persons.context: SEC Associate Director with whom the author filed his initial TCR in 2013.

connections.description: Leon Black described as a 'Milken flunkie'.
Alleged to have orchestrated the VIRT/KCG merger with SEC corruption, writing down billions in fraud assets.
Alleged corrupt relationship where Clayton's former firm (Sullivan & Cromwell) had ties to NITE, and Clayton did not recuse himself.
Dilorio claims his information led to Kamensky's plea deal, but the SEC obstructed further investigation to protect Handler/Jefferies.
Partners in North Island, a top shareholder in NITE/VIRT. Connected through SunGard and NASDAQ transactions.
Piwowar is Executive Director of the Milken Institute Center for Financial Markets, alleged to show Milken's ownership of the SEC.
Both are CEOs of major market makers (Citadel and Virtu) accused of similar illegal naked shorting practices in OTC markets.
Both described as 'second layer players' or 'bag men' involved in money laundering shells and subject to SEC/FINRA actions based on Dilorio's information.

events.title: Knight Capital 'Glitch'
events.description: Knight Capital suffered a massive trading loss due to a software glitch, which the author claims was actually evidence of insolvency from illegal naked shorting and was covered up.

events.title: VIRT/KCG Merger Closing
events.description: Virtu Financial merged with KCG Holdings in a $1.4 billion all-cash transaction. The author alleges the SEC, Handler, and Cifu wrote down over $4 billion in fraud assets to inflate the price, knowing KCG was insolvent.

events.title: OTC Market Volume Explosion
events.description: OTC market share volumes reportedly exploded from 87.7 billion shares in February 2020 to 1.7 trillion shares in February 2021, which the author cites as evidence of massive illegal activity.

events.title: FINRA Complaint Against VIRTU/NITE
events.description: FINRA brought a complaint against VIRTU Americas LLC (fka KCG) for transmitting over 1.5 billion inaccurate ROEs to OATS, which the author cites as confirmation of his money laundering allegations.

events.title: VIRT Q4 2020 Earnings Call
events.description: Virtu Financial reported Q4 2020 results. The author claims the balance sheet fraud was evident, and Cifu admitted retail/OTC trading is a significant driver of revenue.

events.title: Congressional Hearings on GameStop
events.description: House and Senate hearings on GameStop, Robinhood, and retail investing. The author criticizes the lack of questions on illegal naked shorting and the calling of Milken-linked witnesses.

events.title: Dan Kamensky Case
events.description: The author references the SEC/SDNY complaint against Dan Kamensky, alleging the SEC/SDNY are withholding exculpatory evidence to protect Handler/Jefferies.

keyFacts: The whistleblower, Chris Dilorio, alleges the core business of Knight Capital/KCG/Virtu Financial (NITE) is and always has been abusive naked short selling of OTC/pink sheet shells to facilitate money laundering, actively facilitated by a corrupt SEC.
OTC market share volumes allegedly exploded from 87.7 billion in Feb 2020 to 1.7 trillion in Feb 2021, which the author presents as evidence of massive, illegal activity.

The author claims a corrupt relationship exists between the SEC/SDNY and Jefferies CEO Rich Handler, alleging the SEC obstructed investigations to protect Jefferies' interests in the Knight/Virtu merger and the Dan Kamensky case.
The document connects Michael Milken and his associates (Leon Black, Steve Cohen, etc.) to a network of money laundering shells and alleges Milken's influence over the SEC via the Milken Institute.
The author states the SEC created the 'Obligation Warehouse' to allow market makers like NITE and Citadel to circumvent Reg SHO close-out requirements, enabling ongoing illegal naked short selling.
